element_texts.text:
Dunbarton Jan. 11. 1838.
Scrap Book.

  for

Antoinette B. Putnam
Commenced at the age of nine years.

O in thy peaceful path of life,
May no rude thorns be found, 
No sorrow, anguish, care or strife 
Thy bosom's peace to wound. 
But may some sound celestial guide 
Invisible to thee,
By day and night, every side,
Thy constant guardian be. 
He will conduct thy wandering feet 
When the worlds winter lowers 
To meet religious mild retreat
Where bloom perennial flowers. 
And when he leaves his charge at last, 
And thou to earth art given, 
Then may thy spirit that we love, 
Mount safely to the climbs above, 
And find its home in heaven.

To our parents 
1. Father! Mother! do not leave us, 
Go no more from home away; 
O! if you do you sure will grieve us, 
We will be good if you will stay.
2. When we so love to live together, 
Why will you scatter us all around, 
Grandmother, sister, little brother, 
We're all in different placed found. 
3. Tis time our friends, all kindly treat us, 
When we're committed to their care; 
With smiles and words of love they great us, 
And listen to our simple prayer. 
4. But "home sweet home" to us is dearer, 
A mother's smile - a mother's kiss,  - 
And when we're fondly gathered near her, 
O! no where else is joy like this. 
Father! Mother! Do not leave us, 
Your long, long journeys, how we dread. 
So rush up home, O! how you grieve us, 
It seems as tho' you both were dead.

6  If kinds of friends come, or strangers passing,

   They ring, & wait, & ring again;
   Then go away, but not a regressing,
   For they have tried & can't get in.

7  And when we go to seek a blessing,

   Where christians weekly meet to pray;
   A father from his place is missing,
   O; how we wish he would not stay.

8  When sunday comes, some strangers preaching

   We cannot hear our father pray;
   And we have no kind mother's teaching,
   We sigh to think she's far away.

9  Dear parents, will you, can you leave us,

   Do, all this winter with us stay;
   O; soon again you must not greave us,
   By going from "home, sweet home" away.

A. B Putnam
H. M. Putnam
G.A. Putnam

Extracts from Madame Celnarts Book of Politeness

Hot weather or cold and rainy is not an excuse for carelessness in dress.
To make a noise in walking is entirely at variance with good manners.
A lady aught not to hurry in walking.
If a person of your acquaintance is at the window and you are thought to perceive them you aught to address a salutation to them.  But it is necessary to avoid speaking to them from the street or of making signs to them.
The lady of a house does not attempt to take the hats' of gentlemen except she wishes to treat them with familiarity and this is seldom done in calls' of pure ceremony.
Do not be lavish in salutations in meeting people and in taking leave of them.
In winter the most honorable places are those at the corner of the fire place.
If a lady who receives compan a half ceremonious visit is sewing she aught to leave off immediately and not resume it except at the request of the visitor.  If they are on quite intimate terms she aught herself to request permission to continue.  If a person visits in an entirely ceremonious way it would be extremely impolite to work even for an instant.

The Bible.
This little book I'd rather own
Than all the gold and gems
That e're in monarch's coffers shown--
Than all their diadems:
Say, were the seas one chrysolite
The earth a golden ball,
And diadems the stars of night,
This book is worth them all.
"Here, he who died on Calvary's tree
Hath made that promise blest,
Ye heavy-laden, come to me,
And I will give you rest.
A brused reed I will not break,
Nor contrite heart dispise;
My burden's light, and all who take
My yoke shall win the skies."

[sketch of reverse triangle]

Youth is not rich in times; it may be, poor;
Part with it, as with money, spearing: pay
No moment but in purchase of its worth;
And what its worth, ask death beds; they can tell.

The Gift
Take, O take the gift I bring,
Not the blushing rose of spring,
Not a gem from India's cave,
Not a coral of the wave,
Not a wreath to deck thy brow,
Not a ring to bind thy vow;
Brighter is the gift I bring-
Friendship's purest offering.
"Take the book" O, may it be
Treasured long and deep by thee
Wealth may bury thee richer toys,
Love may weave thee brighter joys,
Hope may sing a sweeter lay,
Pleasure shed a softer ray;
But not love, nor wealth, may twine
Wreath so pure as this of mine;
Hope nor pleasure spread a hue
Half so lasting, half so true.
Keep, O keep the gift I bring;
It is friendship's offering.

Lives on the close of school.
Teachers; friends; companions; listen
While the parting note we raise
Hence away we now must hasten
From the scenes of choicest days.
Happy circle Happy Circle
Friendships ties most now be riven.
Swiftly have the moments hasted
Since the hour when first we met
But the pleasantness we have tasted
Long will be remembered yet.
Sweet the memory & C.
Of the days enjoyed here.
Pleasant is the recollection
Of those houres to friendship given
But how solemn the reflection
They will be recviewed in heaven
O how solemn!  yes tis solemn
They are all recorded there.
Then when suns and worlds have perished,
When the last loud trump has pealed,

6.

How lovely was my Mary Ann,
Her heart was joined with mine,
I can't forget the tender love,
Which did our hearts entwine.

                  7.

And though her bosom heaves no sigh,
And labors not for breath,
I can't forget the sickness sore,
She bore before her death.

                   8.

Once on the earth together we,
Could  join in solemn prayer,
We cheerfully were surrounded by,
Gods providence and care.

                  9.

But oh' how soon nine years rolled round,
Earths sweetest flours had bloomed,
Like early fruit or budding flowers,
My daughter is a cut down.

                10.

My sorrows seed the lovely spot,
Where thou doth rest in hope,
And look by faith unto that day,
When Christ shall raise thee up.

1848
Illinois April 2, Sabbath
To day I have had the privilege of attending meeting at Lockport and have heard two excellent sermons from Mr.  Porter the minister there.  In the foreword he preached from Acts "And the Lord added to the Chh.. daily of such as should be saved"  In the afternoon from John 16:14 "Ye are my friends if ye do whatsoever I command you."  We must do the will of God every day, be Christians all the time or we are not his disciples.  No reliance is to be plead on past experience; we are to judge from what we now are, from the evidence we now have.  I hope I shall derive good from what I have heard, and be incited to greater diligence to make any calling and election sure, I am more and more convinced of the depravity of my heart.  Oh! that I might see sin as God sees it.  My thoughts are full of vanity and wickedness - would that I had more peace.
Apr 9 Sabbath, have again been to that at Lockport, Hope should I remain here, to attend regularly there, it was communion day and a precious sermon we had. 21 persons had been examined for admission to the Chh all but two or three of them who detained by sickness, were present

and united. Some by letter and a No. on profession of faith, the fruit of a late revival.  I enjoyed the day much - thought of home & friends, O for more grace - more zeal for God.  I do feel anxious that sinners may be converted - God gives me a heart to work for him, Not one of my dear pupils that I am aware are prepared for death.  May 9, with God's help, do some good here.
April 16th Went to Lockport to chch in the forenoon and  heard Mr, J Codding of Waukesha. Wis. preach from  Rom 8-7 - the carnal heart is enmity etc. This afternoon have attended the funeral of a girl of 12 who died about three miles from here.  Death is constantly and faithfully doing its work.  O how solemn is the thought - that I must die - how unconcerned do I feel and yes it may be very near.  Lord revive me - set my sins in order before me and make me truly penitent - more devoted to thee.

April 23 - Today attended the funeral of a child of three years, who died suddenly.  Her parents I know and they sent their oldest child to school to me.  They were very much attached to this little one, and are almost heartbroken at the separation.  The parents not professors, but both indulged hope some years since.  I do hope they will be revived, that they will see the hand of God in this dispensation - feel its power and yield - yield forever and henceforth live only for God.  God grant also that the warning may be blessed to me.  I am astonished at the hardness of my sinful heart - surely naught but sovereign power can cleanse me effectually from Sin.  God grant renewing grace.
Apr. 29 to day received a letter from my dear very dear parents - in reply to my last in wh. for the first time I stated that I had been troubled with "fever and ague" the great foe to health in this western land.  My health has been good but better at the time since I came

here, but I had not one idea of returning and was quite surprised when I found on reading my letter that they were anxious to have me come.
But dear mother's health, they also wrote was delicate and in consideration of that and my own health and the decided wish of my parents, I decide to go home.  I leave a glorious enterprise in the service of which I have been happy, and where though among strangers and far from relatives I have been perfectly contented.  I have had some trials, but as consciousness that I was discharging my duty to the best of my ability has proved a balm for every wound.  Now, providence favoring my designs I leave in a few weeks for my dear New Eng. and my home.  With pleasure I could stay, and labor to be useful here, but duty calls me.  May God preserve my precious mother's life, yet a long time.

spear Oh! spear her yet longer to do still further good with his blessing, for her children and all her friends - thanks to my creator for such parents - may I ever appreciate their worth and love them in return, and let that love flow out into action.
Apr. 30 - went to chh.  Mr Paddock and wife {with whom I board} went with me - The first time they have been to Lockport to chh for some time - God bless the truth to this family and make it specially a family of prayers -  give me a heart to pray ardently - fervently for this-
May 7 - Went to chh Mr. Porter preached two most excellent sermons on the observance of the Sabbath - I do hope they will do much good - was not able to stop to Sabbath School.
May 14. Sabbath day - was able to stop at morn and hear a class in the Sabbath School.  I think I

do wish to do good the little while I yet remain in this county.  If God but grant his blessing on my efforts it- is all I need wish.
May 17 - The days of another year of my life are numbered and finished.  The  question returns this day with fever; am I nearer heaven as I am nearer eternity?
Nineteen years of life's short journey have fled & What a dream is life and how little how very little do I realize the rapidity with which is passing away.  -nineteen years! ((unclear)) In childhoods hours, I viewed this period, as far distant but now that God has spared my life to attain it, it seems but a day, a short lived day.
Oh; could I feel that my time had been passed in glorifying my creator, all would be happiness but I have many, many things to regret and to repent of.  Would that I could atone for the past but since this cannot be

let my services know a warning & lead me to greater watchfulness and more sincere devotedness to my Savior.  This world - how many temptations it presents "to draw me from the skies - my only hope is in God.  Oh! for his sustaining grace, that I may resist all evil.
May 29. Sabbath, Have again had the privilege of attending worship.  Mr. Porter preached in the forenoon from Matth 23.23 - "These things ought to have done and not to leave the other undone."  The design was to show that all duties - those that are termed little as well as those of more importance should be attended to -both are equally binding.  If we would avoid being classed by our Savior with the hypocritical Pharasees we must perform every duty though some of them be taken by the world small, yet these little things are of great movement. Elder Knapp in the afternoon

preached from Gen. 32-26 "I will no let the go, except thou bless me. On the importance of prayer - private, domestic and public; and the manner in which it should be performed.
June 18  The day has been one of unusual interest to me, as I expect it will be the last Sabbath I spend here. I see so much to be done here. So large a field for usefulness that I feel at times a great desire to remain and do my mite with god's help, but I think it my duty to return. May God safely conduct me back, and assign in his providence a sphere of usefulness. Oh for more devotion to the cause of my Saviour. This hard, cold heart of mine clings to me yet. Oh for more love, more faith. God grant my sins may be forgiven.

Mr. Porter of Du Page preached from Eph. 3-15. The whole family in heaven - Subj. The nature of the fellowship of Christians in Heaven. Afternoon. from Rome 4-13.

 ______________________________

July 10. 1848. This evening I find myself after more than a years absence, once again at my own dear home. Find my mother's health more feeble than I had expected, but she thinks she is gaining. How thankful should I be to that Good God who has been my guide & guard and has brought me safely home, and prolonged the life of my dear parents , brother & sister, and permitted us to meet this happily after a long separation. O may I show my gratitude by striving more than ever to be useful.
July 11. This morning, dear mother went to ride and came back with both bones of the right leg broken! How unexpected! How little we know what is to be our lot - weeks and perhaps months of painful confinement are before her.
Dear father is absent and possibly will not be back for three weeks unless the state of mother's health requires his return - mother does not wish us to send for him.
O my Heavenly Parent - aid me in every duty.

for much, very much now devolves on me.
Dec. 26 1848
About five months have past since last I wrote - my short life never knew a busier time than these few months have been - Today I have been made happy by the arrival of two dear friends who were with me at Gilmanton three years ago - Miss Peavey & Miss Webster. I have not seen them before since we parted at G. O how delightful is the intercourse of friends and how pleasant to meet them and to be permitted a free interchange of thought & feeling.
Dec. 29. Augusta & Emilia left this morning - when shall we meet again? One only knows - it may be, never on earth. But may the friendship which has been commenced below, be continued perfect in the bright & beautiful world above, where we shall know no parting.
30 - Snowed most of the day - towards night it cleared away and we had a most beautiful sunset - brother H took Jane & I out a short distance in the sliegh - spent the day in writing for father - copying parsing exercises. In the evening read account of the discoveries of gold in California.

31. Sabbath - The last day of 1848. Father preached Forenoon from 2.Peter 3-14. Afternoon Gen 25-32 Both very solemn discourses - At noon the bell tolled for the death of Mr. Benj. Whipple who has for some time been sick and not expected to live. - by Father! I thought then that my life is spared while others are called to bid a long adieu to Earth. This has been a year of mercies to me. Safely have I been returned to my home from a distant western station preserved during my journey from many dangers - Perhaps many which I knew not of and permitted by my kind Father to meet my friends on this side eternity. - Then my dear mother has been supported through much sickness and pain - through God's goodness her precious life is prolonged and her children yet are favored with her example & blessed in answer to her prayers - Oh may our parents have the satisfaction of seeing all their children walking in the narrow path that leads to life. My God! I would adore the goodness who has attended me from thy bountiful hand. Thanks to thy glorious name for all thy favors - In me I pray a humble heart that I do little mind them and grant me grace to live for thee and for thy blessed cause. I need thy constant aid - my sinful depraved heart is ever leading me from

thee - Thou only canst aid me & to thy care would I commit my spirit, to thee would I look for help to spend the coming year for thee!
Jan 1. 1849 - The bright sun of the New Year has risen and I am permitted to behold it. Let me commence this year in the fear of God with new resolutions that I will live more as if I realized my destiny, and the great interests which are to be decided by the manner in which these fleeting years are improved, May I so spend this year that with pleasure I can look back on its scenes, and say with confidence that God has been my helper - 
Jan 2. Sabbath. The first Sabbath of the year - a solemn day - I have now enjoyed it some - there is so much sin mingled with all I do that I am often tempted to doubt whether I have any grace - may this lead me to greater watchfulness and more earnest prayers. I do hope the preaching of the word to day will not be without good results. May God speedily review his work here & bring many to the knowledge of himself.
This evening mother and I had our usual season of prayer - O may her precious life

be spared. I sometimes feel many fears respecting her. O that I might be made willing to leave all with God who knows what is best, if it can be thy will, my father, spare her life & health, but more. How all I would desire that each of us may be submissive to the designs of heaven, and at least meet a whole family in this new year in such a manner that should I live to behold its close, I may be able to say I am nearer to heaven. God help me to labor for his cause and to be the instrument of some good. Let me example before my brothers & sister be such that it will religiously lead them to the Savior - what a responsibility rests upon me with regard to them. God also can enable me to discharge my duty.

----------Jan. 14. Rather a thin meeting to day on account of bad weather. Our church smoked so badly that a great part of those who did come went to the Baptist house.
     This week we have heard of the deaths of Mr. & Mrs. Bayley. Mr. B. had been sick and not expected to recover for some time - his wife, as well as usual until a

few days before her death. Thus the kind of terrors is making rapid and sure progress everywhere - young and old, the Gay and thoughtless, and the Christian waiting submissively the summons are alike his prey.

   And how strange, how passing strange that the living had so little the warnings so constantly occurring. A kind father sees our worldliness and note our wanderings, and if common providences fail, to lead us to himself, he sends his minister of death into the circle of our acquaintance and removes one, who has mingled often with us, to the scenes of another being. If our hearts are so hardened that this warning passes without leading us to himself he comes still nearer and takes? from our fond embrace. Some dearly loved relative leaves us to mourn their loss. O should we not acknowledge our father's hand in all our sorrows and feel that not one is in vain - and how should it humble us to think that we need so much to lead us away from earth to God.

Feb. 4. Sabbath. Unusual service was preached the congregation. O1 that God's spirit would come, with its almighty energies, and rouse us, who profess to be Christians, from our slumbers, and convict & convert sinners.

    Have been thinking to night of the dear band of teachers now laboring in the west. It is my prayer that they may have god's blessing and be the instruments of great and lasting good. I do feel more and more that the West is a field of very great importance. The work of evangelising it is the work of God, and he will carry it forward.

Feb. 11. Sabbath. Mr. Ellis preached in the afternoon in behalf of Western Colleges, and Mr. Emerson in the forenoon presented the cause of the Protestant Society, exceedingly interesting. Yesterday received a Report of the Board of Ed. at the West. It made me feel as if I could hardly remain at home- it is a glorious work, this in which they are engaged, it is god's work. O may he prosper those employed in it- may they see of the fruit of their labors in the commission of many souls.

Sabbath Feb. 18. I have lived to see another Sabbath and to enjoy its blessed privileges; but O! how now I improve them - truly my heart is deceit-ful above all things and desperately wicked. Nothing but the blood of Christ can cleanse it. God grant me a spirit of fervent prayer that I may be more devoted to his blessed service. O that I could see my sins in their true light, and repent of them in dust and ashes. I am daily adding to the dark catalogue. When shall I do my duty to my god and to my fellow beings, when will my example be what it ought, and my life be devoted to God's service. When will this wicked heart no longer lead me astray!
Feb. 22. The day of prayers for Colleges quite a full meeting at the vestry. O! may god's Spirit descend in answer to the prayers of his people and convert many of those young men who are being educated in our Seminaries, and make them heralds of salvation to perishing souls.
Feb. 24. Sab. Intelligence reached us this morning of the sudden death of Sarah Wingate at South Hadley. Her father having

received new of the dangerous sickness left home Friday morning (Feb. 23) for Hadley. She lived about four hours after his arrival. Last evening Dea Wingate and Susan with the lifeless remains of the loved daughter and sister reached their home. "O unexpected stroke!"  How must it full those stricken hearts with anguish! May that God who "gave" and who has taken, support the mourning friends; and I may God's repeated providences not pass unheeded by any. How often are we warned of our frailty. Le me think of my end and be prepared for eternity. O let not this event serve to harden my heart but to lead me nearer to Christ & heaven.
Feb. 26. To day attended the funeral of S. Wingate. O can I bear the thought - that the solemn scenes and impressions of to day will ever be forgotten- forbid it, my Father in Heaven. O keep me by thy power from all that can offend thus, and prepare me for death whenever it may come. Sanctify this also to the youth in this place - may they learn their end and seek in Christ a refuge from the curse of sin.

March 3 -1849. This evening dear mother and I have had as usual our Saturday evening in seasons of prayer. How grateful ought I to be for my parents, may I love them and honor them as long as they are spared to me.

I do hope that this evening finds me nearer to heaven than I was a week since, blessed be God if it is true. O may I labor more for God and show to the world that I do love the souls of men.
  March 7. Attended the funeral of Mrs. Fulton at the alms house. Not a single relative to follow her to the last resting place of the body. O it seemed sad to think of it, and yet her situation, lonely as it seemed, was far more enviable, yes infinitely more so, than that of the proudest noblest form on earth, that leaves the world unreconciled to God. Her spirit has gone back to its god and now holds converse with God's angel and the great & good of former times. Angels were her convoy, to conduct her to a blissful home. Her sightless eyes are opened now,  they will behold forever the glorious light of heaven's eternal day.

O happy change - surely we need not mourn the dead in christ.
March 11. The services of this Sabbath have been very solemn and impressive. I do hope good will be the result, & that God's spirit may be poured out abundantly on this people. If the young could only realize the solemnity of death and feel that it must come to them how could they be otherwise than alarmed at their situation. In God is all the sinners hope- how sweet to feel that he is our friend - what a glorious hope is the Christians!
March 14  Last night watched with Mrs. Bailey. She is a dear good woman - no one could help admire her lovely and christian deportment during her long illness. God be praised for blessing earth with a spirit like hers, so calm & happy, so sweetly resigned to the will of Heaven. O may the impressions I have received during the hours spent with her never be erased fr. my mind. Death never seemed so great  & solemn - a change was never

did a savior's presence & support appear of so priceless value.  It does seem to me that if a person once seriously reflects on death and the scenes immediately to follow, the result must be a full and hearty confession that some all seeing power is requisite, which earth can never yield, where else but in the mighty God who has made us and redeemed us, can this aid be found! O let me henceforth live with my end in view, and forget this world at least comparatively forget it to such an extent that I may constantly remember eternity and prepare for its transactions.
19. To day attend the funeral of Mrs. B. I do hope I may truly say it was good for me to be there. I learned my end and the end of all mankind. The noblest loftiest form must "lie" lo in the ground? But the spring, the breath of the Almighty, lives on eternally. It lays aside this frail, worn out

casket, wh. enshrined it and, all untrammelled takes its flight to its native atmosphere. O the glory of the Christian's hope. Truly in the Savior, depending alone on his merits, the Christian passes safely through earths trying scenes and by the same kind hand is led through death dark valley onward to the gate of heaven - this he enters "to go no more out forever!" "O blest abode" there to spend eternity and be evermore with our Savior one like him. May I hope for such a porter with all my sin? Blessed be God through Christ, I may. Then let me live for my Creator - devote myself unreserved to his service, soul and body.
Sabbath March 25. Text in the forenoon 1 Thess. 4 -14 "sleep in Jesus" To fall asleep in Jesus is to die in the full possession of a good hope in Christ - that hope wh., is an "anchor to the soul." O the blessedness of this hope - how it sustains the soul in trial, and sorrow; and, even on the bed of death.  Now is all fear dispelled and every foe to peace disarmed, if Christ be the refuge of the soul. More

and more am I convinced of my own utter helplessness . O my soul plea to that Savior, and trust entirely in his merits - he is sufficient to save them - all polluted as thou art, and covered thick with wicked sins - he died for thee, though thou wast then a bitter enemy. What unbounded  love, what infinite condescension.
March 31 Have been reading an article by Mrs. Stowe on the ministrations of departed spirits in this world. It is a delightful soul-cheering idea that the glorified happy spirits of those we love have not wholly left us - they love us still. and are free to minister to our wants and, without doubt, hover unseen around us, and whisper words of consolation and joy. If this be the case, as I am inclined to believe, how "brightly gleams our pathway" though life! We then overwhelmed with sorrow and trouble and trials may we not imagine ourselves surrounded by a "cloud of witnesses" loving with God-like benevolence, and power

granted by Heaven to dispel all desolations and fill our world with peace "like a river". Glorious thought, blessed be God for giving, in his word, evidence of its truth.
1849 Apr. 29 Leonard Parker preached to day. His subject in the forenoon was on the respect & reverence due the heavy headed. He spoke very impressively of the duties of children to their parents, and of the results of disregarding these duties. I feel that I am guilty in this respect. Lord aid me to give my precious parents "honor due" - To labor with my might - for their happiness. Who more deserves my care?

  The afternoon text was from Heb. 12, 1 "Let us lay aside every weight and the sin wh. doth so easily beset us."
 I have recently written two or three little notes to some associates. Let my most fervent prayers for God's blessing accompany them. Nothing I know can be accomplished without divine aid. O that God's work might be revived here, that his wondrous power might be made manifest.

May 1. Laboring with my might to prepare myself to go to Amherst on Friday. Am very unexpectedly called to S. to take the place of E. Allison in a school.
May 4.  Spend the night at Esy Allison's in Manchester.
May 5. reached S. today - come by stage from Manchester. Board at Dea. Goodnow a very pleasant family.
May 6. Attended  ch. heard Mr. Moor preach three were admitted to the church in the afternoon, at the communion season. Two of them were baptized. Joy has been caused in heaven over their repentance & may many more here be led to the Savior without delay.
May 13 Sunday  Mr. Davis preached in the forenoon from  "Choose ye this day whom ye will serve, as for me and my house we will serve the Lord." Design of the discourse to show the religious duties of parents to their children. In the afternoon the verses describing the healing of blind Bartimaeus were the foundation of the discourse - sabbath school chr. were particularly addressed.

  I have been reading Mrs. Judsons memoirs I hope it is my sincere desire that it should incite me to greater zeal for God. What very nothingness are all my endeavors. Oh! that God may work in me and by me and permit me to be an instrument of some good. How responsible is my situation 45 immortals under

my care through the week. God help me to be useful to them - let me not be inactive in his service but may I love to labor for him with my might. Lord, my hope is in thee -appear for me, I beseech thee, and enable me to conquer all difficulties, in thy strength; to thee shall be all the praise eternally.
Amherst May 17, 1849 It must be that another whole year of my life is gone. O life, what a frail, fleeting thing thou art - a bubble even gone ere we know that thou art here. May God, my Maker, help me to realize to such an extent the vanity of this life, that I may be enabled to prepare, as I ought, for the life to come. This Lord, unfeeling heart - how shall it be made to feel with power, the Great truths of the Gospel? In God is my help; there is none that I desire beside him, may he be my eternal portion, and I need ask no more. I cannot wish to be more blessed. Come thou, my Savior, and dwell forever with me, for thou hast promised to be with the least, and most sinful of thy children - grant me grace, I beseech thee to discharge all my duties in thy fear, and guide me, O guide me in thy truth and suffer me not to disgrace thy holy cause.
May 20. Yesterday I heard the cheering intelligence that a gracious revival is in progress in

the neighborhood where I taught in Illinois. Some of my own dear pupils are among the converts - blessed be God for his goodness. and may his spirit be poured out more abundantly still, and many more be brought into the fold of Christ- O for a heart to labor for God - how very little I have ever done for him- may I be willing to take up my cross and follow Christ through evil & through good report. I have daily occasion to thank God for his goodness to me - his loving kindness is over all the work of his hand - to me he has shown unmerited favor all my life long.
May 27.  A lovely sabbath morning this & may its quiet stillness be an emblem of that peace and joy which shall fill many a heart this day. I hope I do feel some gratitude to God for his goodness to me. How much does the world owe to the religion of Jesus. How it soothes and sustains the soul in trial; and in prosperity it brightens every joy. I feel more and more convinced that piety is happiness- "the sunshine of the heart, the Sabbath of the soul, the resting place on which the heart lays down its load of cares & anxieties and sorrows." Blessed be God that he has given the least reason to hope that

my soul possesses one little spark of this living, vital Home. Help me, my Savior to strive to bring others to a knowledge of thy glorious self and of the happiness wh. thy religion only can afford.
June 3. Mr. Richards of Nahshua preached to day -  in the forenoon from the words "He will hear thee again of this matter." In the afternoon, "Thou and beside thyself, much learning doth make thee mad." Both discourses exceedingly interesting. Have enjoyed the preaching more than usual. May it be blessed to my soul's eternal good.
June 10. Mr. Emerson preached. He is agent for the Protestant and Evangelical Society. Text in the forenoon. 2 Sam.24-26 Phil. 2-4. Afternoon. I wish I and all who profess to be the friends of Jesus felt more deeply interested in these great benevolent movements and were more willing to aid in their advancement. O! to be more like the Savior - to have more of his spirit.

My school occupies many of my thoughts & I have very many fears that I am not doing all in my power for the good of my pupils - my hope is in God may I be aided this week in every duty.

My hearts desire and prayer to God is that I may be the means of doing some good here.
June 17. Mr. Davis preached in the forenoon from "Be kindly affectioned one towards another" etc. In the afternoon "First take the beam from thine own eye"etc.  Excellent sermons.
June 24. Mr. Moore of Milford.
July 1. Mr. Davis "Ye shall be my sons and daughters, said the Lord " etc.

        Three persons were admitted to the church to day - a very interesting season God's work seems to be progressing here, silently. How I should delight to learn that his work was going on at D. How long, O Lord, will thou withhold thy Spirit? O send it down in rich showers and make known thy power & grace in converting many souls to Christ. Help me to feel that thy cause is worth everything else.
  I bless God that he has preserved the life and health of my dear parents and friends thus far

in my absence. Many, many things have I for which to praise thy name, my God, and yet all undeserving of thy mercy.-
-- My life, and various events in it, seem strange indeed to me. For what God is preparing me I know not  - his will be done.
July 8. Mr. Wallace preached in the forenoon from Psalms 17 - 15. I shall be satisfied, when I awake, with thy likeness. In the afternoon from Math. 25- 30. And cast ye the unprofitable servant into the outer darkness-- In the forenoon showed that no person is perfectly satisfied in this life - not even the Christians - all have a longing for something not possible. But there is a time coming when the true disciples of Jesus, will be satisfied. When they awake in the likeness of their Savior.

 This as well as the afternoon sermon furnished abundant theme for self examination.  How dreadful the fate of those who do not awake in their Savior's likeness? Spare me O Lord this shame and confusion of face, and grant that I may be, in some measure, like thyself.

July 15 - Mrs. Davis, from Eph 4 -14-15, O! I am so wicked. So worldly, I feel as though God would have nothing to do with me. I do many, many wicked things- may my heavenly Father remember that I am but dust - a sinful erring, mortal.

   My I have divine assistance in my school duties this week - this alone can make me successful. I bless God for the favors already shown me, and ask though all unworthy, a continuance of his favors & about two weeks I hope to be well through with my school, and thinking of home, sweet home.

July 21 - Closed my school today and expect to go home tomorrow with my dear father who is home.
Aug. 5  Sabbath. My brothers both at home. Our kind heavenly parent has permitted us to meet again thanks to his glorious name for all his goodness. Let all that is within me praise his name.Thy goodness Lord knows not a bound. Thou rememberest thy creatures though sinful

& erring.  O make us all thine own- prepare us for thy will whatever it be.

Aug 26 - Sabbath. Father preached to day - O may the memory of the sermons go with me through the week.
            How prone - how very prone and to wander, this world, though I know it is vain & will soon pass away, occupies far too many of my thoughts - no one but God can help me. O may I be more active for God. My conscience tells me I do very little, very little. One week from tomorrow {it changed ?} I am again, prov. permitting the return of the responsibilities of teaching - may divine aid be mine. I feel my insufficiency.

Sept. 3 - commenced school at Goffstown.
Sept. 11. May God aid me this day in every duty - he knows my need & may I trust wholly in him.

         The passage for today in Daily Guide is - "Brother give dilligence to make your calling by election sure - for if you do these things, ye shall never fall." Let me

Oct 25 - Mr. Hitchcock from Exeter Psa 119  -58 & Phil. 3: 20"
_____________________________________________________
Dunbarton Nov. 1. 1846. Mr. Patrick of Canterbury Rom. 13-10 & Phill 1-28 


[left margin] 19 years old
Nov. 6. Daniel Jameson died. 61. how are all and especially the young, warned to be ready for death when we think not of it, when all is brought before us, - death cold death may come, and, an instant, without any warning we may be hurried from the scene of time to that of an untried eternity. O Let me search my heart and try to be prepared for a mansion above, when death comes.
Nov. 8. Heard this morning of the death of Phebe Mills, D. Jameson's friend today - 29 years old - another in the morning of life is called to bid adieu to the world- may these providences be sanctified to all. I know not when my time may come perhaps before another Sabbath morn shall dawn, perhaps before another hour is passed.

O that I felt more the importance of being ready. Father preached from this text. Job 7: funeral sermon. Communion in the afternoon.

Think much of this to day.
Sept, 16. I am spending this Sabbath at Goffstown - went home last Sabbath.

  Miss Cook, I found was failing rapidly. Let me think what would be my feeling were I in her situation. Her poor mother can hardly speak of her without weeping, but she has the consolation of knowing that her daughter has a hope of heaven.
 How often are the young and those who provide much for future usefulness cut down by death's cold hand - called to relinquish all the tender ties that bind the soul to this beautiful world - but, for the Christian, higher joys than earth can give are in store - if one could but have a glimpse of these joys, and feel that they were indeed for them, it would truly take away the sting of death.

This blest assurance Christ alone can give.
Sept. 28.  Another week has forever departed - with what alarming swiftness does time carry me on to eternity. Be it my chief concern while here I stay to do thy will who placed me here - then let the moments fly swift.

as thy will, it only brings a glorious heaven nearer. Lord, help thy sinful child to spend this day for thee. Grant me but the consciousness when night's dark shades shall tell me day is done that this has been a Sabbath, not in vain - this all I ask. I cannot trust this wicked heart - so oft it leads me far away from good. My Savior is my refuge. O for more cordial trust in him, more ardent wishes for his glory, and greater willingness to labor for his causes whenever opportunity presents.

 Oct. 14 - Thanks to kind heaven for Sabbaths. Today I am enjoying it in my room, for though it is a delightful day, I have not the privilege of attending cch. Mr. Wilby is sick and we have no preaching. May God help me to do nothing wrong to day. I fear my Sabbaths, many of them, ill spend - a worldly wicked heart leads me astray from god and heaven. May heaven bless my father's labors to day and the labors of all the servants of God everywhere.

? to Monday.
Nov. 25- yesterday my school closed- thanks to God for his goodness to me - truly I ought to be grateful for so many favors shown by my heavenly Father- O let me not forget his benefits.

    I think I have today, been enabled to think less than usual of the power of this world and more of the aprobation of heaven may it ever be thus.

Dec. 20 - the last Sabbath in the year 1849 - O how many serious thoughts rush to the mind as the coming of this day tells me that the year is almost spent. One day more and its precious hours will all be gone. It seems but a moment since we wrote 1840 and now ten years are added to the No. and ten more will pass as rapidly away to join their fellows. But I may not behold their close. O let me ask what is my state of preparation to enter upon an endless eternity?. Am I any nearer to a heaven of joy than I was one year since? This heart is very full of sin. I feel more than ever that nothing but the grace of God can save me. I have for some time been endeavoring to correct some bad habits - to exercise kind feelings always never to suffer one angry passion to rise - but

I am fearful I have not sought help of my Savior as much as I ought in these attempts & if I do for once gain an advantage over these wrong emotions I am apt to give myself the glory of it. O for aid from above, make me, O my Father, more like my Savior. "Jesus be thou my pattern." I do think I desire to be wholly thine - to give thee all. Help me to live as though I wished to be thine entirely.
Jan. 1, 1850  The new year has come. I know that time is bringing me rapidly on towards eternity. O that I could feel it more - Eternity - what a world of meaning in the word - how startling is the thought that I have commenced a life which can never end. O my Savior help me by thy mighty power to live not for this world but for Heaven. I feel I am sinful and unworthy but thou are pure and holy - thy merits "will atone for me," and thine alone. Help me to serve thee with more zeal than ever, What have I ever done for thee.
Jan. 7. The first Monday in 1850. we had a meeting in the vestry all day as we are accustomed on the first Monday of the year. In the forenoon were the anniversaries of the various benevolent societies. In the afternoon we had one of the best meetings

1850

we ever had -a great many of the church members spoke and spoke with much feeling. I do hope it is the beginning of good things. The important period of time in which we live was the great topic of conversation. We are just entering upon the last half of the present century. Who can but "be sober" when thinking of what has taken place during the last 50 years and what will take place ere this century departs. Most who now live and act will then be in their graves - others will fill their places.  sometimes thoughts like these make me sad - at other times there is pleasure -real true pleasure in the thought of exchanging this simple earth for a bright heaven where I shall see Jesus and live with him forever. O that I could feel sure that Christ is mine and I am his. I desire no greater joy than this. O let me live for Christ that I may have his presence in death.
Jan. 13. Sab. Two more sermons I have heard this day for wh. I must render an account to my God. I have to lament my worldliness & vanity. O when will sin no

longer have dominion over me. Let me strive with my might to enter in at the straight gate. In Christ is my hope, of myself I can do nothing.
Sab. Jan. 20. Father preached in the forenoon & Mr. Cook in the afternoon. Thank God that I have been enabled to think less of the world than usual this day.  Still my wicked heart binds me far to strongly to earth. I know I do not strike as I ought to enter in at the straight gate. My heavenly Father may well withhold his presence from me. ? would I be more devoted to his service here.

I wonder that I can feel so little for my dear brothers and sister & other friends who are without hope. Let me reflect how uncertain is life & that at any moment they are liable to be removed to another state of existence to be forever happy or miserable forever & can I rest - can I be unmoved? O my Father, grant thy Spirit, let it come over me with Almighty Power. I will pray more than ever for its descent. "Perhaps Will hear my cry."

______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Wed. eve. Jan. 23. A most glorious evening How much I do enjoy this great moonlight and these twinkling lights scattered all about.

I thank my Father for this beautiful earth and that I am permitted to see and to love its glories. O may they lead me to worship more supremely, their more glorious Author.

______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Jan. 27 - Sab. I hope I am somewhat thankful for the blessings of this holy day. The sermon contained some important hints with regard to prayer. Shall endeavor to remember them and with divine aid to practice them. Prayer is indeed the "Christians vital breath," "his native air." It is a precious privilege to go to the throne of grace - may I feel it more and more.


Feb. 3. Sab. How beautiful is this twilight of this sabbath day. Who could look at those bright clouds wh. speak so eloquently yet silently of Him - the glorious Architect of all things and not feel their inmost soul subdued, and melted into love. I thank thee my kind Father for the glory of this earth thy footstool. In wisdom hast thou fashioned all. O for a heart to praise Thee more.

Feb. 10 Not able to attend church today. The bell is just calling the assembly together. How solemnly its note falls on my ear. Its duty now is a cheerful one, but sometimes it has a mournful task to discharge, sometimes it speaks, in tomes most thrilling, a souls departure. I know not for whom it will next discharge this sad office. May God's grace prepare me for death whenever it shall come. I do often fear that I am living in false security. I do not feel that ardent desire for the conversion of others that I wish & ought to feel. My heart seems to me more wicked than ever. I know I feel that without Heavenly aid, I cannot become one particle better. I cannot even lose the control of one single bad habit. My Father, help me to trust in thy strength. O subdue the angry feelings that so often rise in this heart - let me feel when this new week is done that I have made some progress in conquering them. Thine should be the praise.

value of time
Feb. 17. O the wickedness of this heart. How thankful should I be that God has placed me in the midst of so many incentives to good. What should I have been had I the temptation to evil and sin that some have. But for all my advantages I must render an account. This sabbath day, I wished I though I wished, to shut out earth and think and speak of glorious heaven, but thoughts of this world have been very often intruding. O, this heart of mine must be very bad -very wicked indeed. But I will not despair--there is a balm in Gilead a physician there to heal the sin sick soul. O that I could go always with the confidence of a child and seek his mercy & pardon.
Feb. 27 - Have read this morning the account of the destruction of the Egyptian host. How forcibly does it tell me God is mighty. Who can stand before him whose is "glorious in holiness, fearful in praises, doing wonders" In God may the Christian rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory. For

He is able to save them to the uttermost.
{March 5, 1850 - Feel rather sadly today, and yet I feel glad in spite of sadness. I almost tremble in view of what I have done - as much for another as for myself. I have by my own decision placed at stake not only my own happiness for life but that of another. O should I ever be the means of causing unhappiness or sorrow to another. How could I ever endure it. But I have prayed for direction from heaven and I do hope God has been a mutual guide.

   I have within two or three weeks had much to try my feelings. My joy is this, that God rules every where and directs even the slightest events. I will trust in him & fear not. I do hope and I can but think and believe, that he has been my guide and led in the path of right. I think I see his guiding hand on all and thus gives me happiness.}

March 17. Let me go to thine house to day my Father feeling that this blessed earthly sabbath is given me to

prepare for a more glorious heavenly rest in thy kingdom above. Suffer me not to go with selfishness and vanity in my heart - root out, I beseech thee these corruptions, and give me a true, earnest, desire that thy kingdom may come, and thy will be done in my own heart and throughout this sinful world. Bless my dear father in his labors to day and make him successful in winning souls to Christ.

 Help him to seek thy glory, as did Christ, & not his own, that he may prove himself this to be a true minister of thy holy gospels.
                                                          March 18. Mr. Cook died this morning.

March 19- Commenced school at Goffstown -38 pupils. O for divine aid in my duties as a teacher. How much I need it - everything depends upon it.
March 24 - Heard Mr. Tully preach this forenoon from the 51 Psalm. He made remarks upon the whole of the portion. In the afternoon his subject was the truth of God, and the duty of Christians to exercise faith in him. O let me go to God for my pupils and see if he will not hear and pour out a blessing. I do desire that they may be Christians, all of them and I will with Gods

help labor for it.
March 31 - A most lovely Sabbath - I often think of God's footstool be so very beautiful, calling forth so many of the heart's best feelings, where must be the throne, the heaven of heavens? And may I, a sinful child, behold the full glories of the Savior amid his father's throne : God only knows.

 Mr. Stone preached from Rom. 14- 7 For none of us liveth, to himself and no man dieth to himself.

April 7 - Mr. Tully preached two excellent sermons to day. I hope they will make me better.

 O my dear scholars -god helps me to do my duty to then. O that I could be the instrument of leading them to seek pleasures beyond earth's fleeting ones, to lay up a treasure in a fairer brighter world of joy.
   I praise God that I have to day had some little sense of his goodness and my own extreme sinfulness. O may I see it more and more.

April 4- At home to day - a strange day and rather a thin meeting but I hope not an unprofitable one.

April 21- This is a most lovely Sabbath evening - so heavenly calm and quiet - What an emblem is such a day, of the rest, the endlessness witness an end of the saints  in heaven above. How much is there in the stillness of a pleasant sabbath evening to inspire in the mind sweet thought of that bright world above where "endless pleasures roll."

Mr. Willey preached in the forenoon from 1 Timothy  4-16 In the afternoon from Psalm 118-15. Most excellent discourses both. O may this faithful servant of God be rewarded for his toils and labors for this people.
   O that I might do more for God. I feel that I am a sinner & a very wicked sinner against God. My heart is sad and it seems to grow no better. O my Savior encircle me in thine arms and keep me from sin and every evil - with thee I am am safe and no where else. O help me not to forget thee.

May 5 - School through at G. closed yesterday. How I do wish I could feel and know that I have done some good, but perhaps this desire arises more from

sinful ambition than from a true desire to God. This heart is so deceitful . How can I ever know whether or not there is any thing good in my heart - but I must do my duty and leave all with Him who alone "knoweth what is in man."

   Have thought more than ever to night of the perfect holiness of God's Law. I think I saw and felt the impossibility of one's keeping it, and living up to its requirements, without the aid of its glorious Author. Not till the body dies perhaps will the soul be free from its bondage to sin, entirely free- holy as God is holy. I feel that I have as yet but just started in the christian course. May God help me to aim at a higher standard of Piety.

May 8 Mr. Hadley called {from Goffstown}
May 9- attended lecture - next Sabbath is communion. May I be aided to examine myself - this is a christian duty - which I have too much neglected. I hardly know how to perform it, but God will aid me. O may I be prepared for the duties of the sabbath.

May 10 - Friday prayer meeting at our house, a number of ? present and a very good meeting. God aid me to lead in prayer- thanks to his name alone.

  - May 11 - Saturday  ? May God aid me in the coming day that I be serious and thoughtful. I think ever sabbath I will try to day to come? to earth but I am not yet able to control my thoughts - perhaps I do not pray enough and aright for divine aid. Lord with thine aid will I endeavor to spend the morrow for thy glory - help me to pray for this with a true desire that it may be accomplished.

May 12 - Communion. I lament this day the worldliness of this heart - my thoughts have not been so constantly on heavenly themes as they might and ought to be. May God forgive and aid me hereafter. I have not enjoyed as much as I hoped I should - probably my own sinful heart prevented. O for more holiness and more humility. I am sensible I do not make effort enough to be always on my guard against temptation.

May 17 - 1850 21 years old this day. It seems sad to think so much of life is gone and I have accomplished so little, so very little. But let me forget the past and press onward, let me strive day by day to grow, intellectually and spiritually. It seems sad to reflect on the rapid flight of years, but why should it be so - should I not rather rejoice. If I was really a true disciple of Jesus should I not be glad and rejoice that the swift departure of days & months and year was bringing me nearer to a haven of eternal rest. O for that blessed assurance  of hope to which some have attained, but perhaps I desire the reward without being willing to live the life that ensures it. Lord search me with thy help I will give myself more than ever this year to the duty of self examination. O help me to make thy glory my chief end while I live. my sinful nature clings to this vain earth. I know my duty, far better than I do it. I do hope I may be enabled to spend this year profitably . I know

not what the year will bring to me, and wisely are its events concealed. The last year has been a happy one - I never have felt more uniformly cheerful, and yet I can say I never had more real trial. My school at Amherst I often think why did I go there, but I doubt not it was in accordance with a wide design of Providence, which, I may one day understand and wh. I may rejoice. Since this events have occurred wh, will give a coloring my whole life -such as I little anticipated when the year commenced, such as I neglected for in the future, if ever to occur. Life seems to me now more like reality? than ever I can truly say this has been the most eventful year of my life. I hope all has been under divine direction, and now my god while Praise to thy name for the rich mercies receiveth shall ascend from the heart of the unworthy creature she would commit herself to thy care, renewedly. In joy and sorrow be thou a present ?end. If prosperity comes let it not lead to forgetfulness of thee. If adversity let it serve the end divine wisdom intended it.

should accomplish . If thou art with me all will be well.
June 2 - M. C. Marshall preached to day Text in the forenoon Math. 22.42 - Afternoon Rom. 8.9 .   Most excellent sermons. I think I can truly say Christ never appeared to me so lovely and excellent- so worthy, so infinitely worthy of the supreme love of all his creatures. so perfectly adopted to all my wants. What could I wish more than such a friend. O let my whole life be his - wholy and forever.
{Beautiful Earth - Who could help exclaiming on such a day as this. O the bliss the rapture of living. If such the glory of the footstool, what must be the throne? Let me so live that I may one day behold with the fullness of joy the perfect splendor the unutterable glory of the Heavenly world.
June 16 - Mr. Willey preached to day from Isiah 6 3-10 & Psalm 25-7. O may I be better for what I have heard today. If I am not better I must be a great deal worse. If I misimprove such preaching what will become of me. But I do think God has been bearer to me than usual this world has not been so prominent in my thoughts as it sometimes is. to God be all

the praise for any good which this hour has wrought. The bible seems more than ever beautiful to me.

                    My father aid me to labor for the conversion of my dear scholars more ardently this week. What is then to prevent my laboring for Christ? Even though I can do but a little, that little I ought to perform. I know it - I hope I feel it in some measure.

Dear mother's health is very feeble. O that it may be God's will to restore her. How happy it would make me to be with her always and minister to her wants. God will direct me and I will trust in him.
June 23  - Enjoyed meeting pretty well today- this heart of mine is hard, O very hard. I yield very, very gradually to the Savior. I do hope there is a little progress, as weeks glide on. Have been thinking today of the influence having of words of imagination on my mind and I decide that I ought to do nothing wh. will have a tendency to make so evil a heart even worse. I think I will avoid stories, as a general

rule of practice, probably some are calculated to benefit. The works of imagination perhaps should not be condemned. How carefully I ought to revise? my reading since there is so much for me to learn that will fit me to live better and life has so short time in wh. to learn it. "Let me then be up and doing" etc.
June 30. Sabbath - No words can tell the beauty of this day.  O that every heart in the universe was tuned to sing His praise who fashioned this fair earth. Father preached to day morn Malachi 3-9 and Job 4- 8&9. I think God was his helper. He has been feeble in body, for many days and we hardly expected he would be able to go through with the services of the day, but, as has often been the case, with the dawn of the Sabbath, came not perfect health but renewed strengths and vigor for the holy duties of the day. May the sermons be blessed to all and may  we speedily be gladdened by tokens of God's presence there. How long, O Lord how long will thou

forsake thine heritage? O leave us not forever - return and revise thy work and glorify thy great name.

  The Conference of Churches met here during the last week and a precious? season we have enjoyed. I almost tremble lest it should pass and no good be accomplished, for such privilege on account must be rendered to God. My Father helps me to improve then as I ought.

19 months here 
July 7. Another lovely sabbath day - How happy does this quiet Sunlight make me - soon the day with its duties and its sacred privileges will be gone. I often feel sad to think the days ply away so rapidly, but I fear this is coming. This week I heard that my dear friend, Ann H. was rejoicing in the Christian alliance. I praise God for his unspeakable goodness.My heart condemns me that I

am not more faithful in my companions and all those with whom I mingle. It is very often in my heart to speak to them, about the soul, but for some reason I shrink from the duty - often the sentence I would speak is all ready for utterance but after all I speak not. I know it is wrong - and what must I do . I will require a great effort for me to correct this foolish & wicked reserve, but a strengthening will aid me in the work.

  Dear mothers health not as good. I know not what trials are before me. O that it may be God's will to spare her life. She is a precious mother and a sister? to me. Through?  joy and sorrow of my life she has showed scarce a thought has been concealed from her. My parents both have ever been very dear to me but I never loved them as now. May God grant them life and health and happiness and his own blest presence always.

July 15 Brother Henry came home from Boston yesterday, where he had been four weeks most of the time sick with a fever.

  He is yet quite sick. O may this prove a blessing to his never dying soul then it will not be in vain. He seems quite serious. I do hope it will not weve? away and have him without God in the world. I do not see how anyone can dare to live on, and feel that God, the mighty ruler of the universe is not a friend. God grant my own dear brother may be saved - through the merits of a risen Savior.
  The text this forenoon was John 12 - 32. "And if I be lifted up from the earth, will draw all men unto me." What magnet more powerful could there be to draw the sinner to Heaven? What more touching and irresistible motives could be presented to lead poor fallen sinners to the only refuge? Strange that my heart is so hard, and I

feel it so little. I sometimes have many doubts and fears lest my hope is not well grounded. Lord search me. I have nothing to plead, no merit of my own. No hope save this. What Thou hast done for me. And that you bidest me come to Thee. Great Lamb of God, I cometh.
________________
Have been thinking to day of the union of Christ and the true believer and the evidence of regeneration afforded by the consciousness of loving those that love Christ, and in whom his image is displayed. Says a writer "all lives terminating in a common center are one in it, so all believers are one in Christ. And as those lives, the more they approach the center, one near to one another, so all believers, the closer the union with Christ, the more they are to each other." How true! And I do think I have felt something of this feeling. to God be the praise!

July 28 Brother H. still sick. If it is God's will I do hope his life will be spared. He hopes he is a Christian. When I came home from school one night last week, he called me to him, and said Nettie you must pray for me. I told him I did. He said "I mean to be a Christian. I am determined to be for Christ" I told him how glad it made me and that I hoped he would always feel so. He said if I do this sickness will be a blessing it will not be for naught. O Savior- make him truly New?.  How can we praise God enough for the evidence we have that he is truly revived. God alone has done it and to his glorious name be all the praise forever.

 Aug. 11 - Since I have written Brother H. has been very, very sick. For several days we relinquished all hope of his

recovery, but he still lives, and is now, we hope, a little better - we think unless something new occurs that he may recover. I ave been out of school two weeks since he came home, expect to commence the last two weeks tomorrow, unless he should be worse again. How grateful we ought to be that his life is prolonged - we feel that he is in the hands of God and that all will be well, whether he lives or dies. It seems like a dream that my br. Henry who has always before been so strong and well, should now be so sick and weak and helpless. When the finger of God touches us, how speedily our strength vanishes. But how delightful it is to feel that we are in the keeping of a Being so wise and powerful and that his will surely will be executed respecting us. It is "sweet to be passive in His hands" "And know no will but His."

Aug. 18 - Sabbath. Mr. Marshall preached two most excellent discourses. In the forenoon from Neh. 4-6 -"For the people had a mind to work"- said much of the results which follow from people's being really in earnest. If the disciples of Christ ere more in earnest in laboring for their master, how much might they accomplish, God helping them. The prophet of Mecca once said, "If the sun were on my right hand against me and the moon on my left I would not give up my work."

  O may I have more of this spirit in laboring for my Savior. Let me strive and pray to possess it.
   The afternoon text was "To what shalt a man profit etc. A very impressive discourse.  O what will become of me if I am not better for listening to such sermons? It is my earnest prayer that I may be a growing Christian.
  O the infinite value of the soul, "it is just worth the price that has been paid for it." O that many here may realize its value before it is too late. The thought of living forever - with

what overwhelming power it sometimes bursts upon me. Immortality "How feebly can a faltering tongue express the vast idea."   O my God, prepare me, prepare everybody in this whole world for a blissful eternity.
_____________________________________
Aug. 25 Sabbath. I write with a sad and heavy heart.  But God has done it and we should not murmur. God has taken my oldest brother, my own dear Henry away from us. He died about eight this morning without one struggle. This earth is no longer his home, but we hope he is gone to a happier home in Heaven. You, to whom my parents were looking for support in the decline of life, on whom the fond hopes of all our little circle were centering, for whom we found our esteem & affections daily increasing - our loved Henry is gone from us forever, that strong arm is unnerved, the silver cord is loosed & the golden bowl is broken we see not now the reason but shall we not one day see and feel that God, in wisdom and love has beneved? us. 
This is indeed a mournful day for us. The rain is falling in torrents - the heavens seem to be weeping in sympathy, but God is good - that Judge of all the earth has done right. He has mingled many mercies with this cup of sorrow. Thanks to his name for the evidence we have that dear H. is safe in a brighter world - this

he has begun the ceaseless song the ransomed sing before the throne. He seemed to have no fear of death. The christian's hope removed entirely the sting.

 Aug. 26 - The last sad duties are performed. Dear H. will no more return to us. O how can I ever believe it. I tremble lest the events of the last week should pass by and make my heart no better. Can I ever think so much of earth again? & how know that I lived in a dying world, but now I seem to feel that death is all around me, and that I too, am not secure. O that the youth here may feel that God speaks to them.

Aug. 31 - Dr. Stevens died this morning. Thus often are we taught our frailty.  Seven weeks tonight dear Henry came home - one week to night was his last night on earth. We little thought when he returned of the wearisome days & nights appointed him. We little thought that in six weeks his days would be finished but so it is. "God gave. He taketh. He will restore." & blessed be his name. But O may Heaven sanctify to me this trial - forbid my Savior, that it

should be in vain.
Sept. 1. I wake this morning, but dear H. sleep never to wake. His eyes are closed forever on this earth. But are they not gathering rapturously on brighter and holier scenes than earth ever knew or its inhabitants ever conceived! I can but hope they are. When the archangel's trumpet shall sound, then shall we know where dwells the spirit. O life be ? what mysteries they are. Who can comprehend the union of flesh and spirit or explain the wonder of this separation when death severs the uniting bond? None but the Infinite.  Fearfully and wonderfully are we made.

  The events of this year have taught me many a lesson. My view of life and all that pertains to is, are greatly changed. My own life, seems passing rapidly away. Joyous childhood is gone, and the light and shadows of youth have departed and I seem now to be looking forward to lifes sober and even solemn realities. Sorrow & trial has begun its work. I knew this was a world of trial- now I begin to fee that it is such. O may I ever keep in view the great end for wh. I live, then though dark clouds

hover over me and the strong fury be discharged upon me, a bright star will gild the gloom.
Sept. 8 - Again  I am by the window where I love to sit, and the silver moon has come with its "one - little star to hold the candle" O how lovely has God made this earth.

 This is the evening of another communion sabbath. O how fearful to think of misimproving these precious days. My heart is very wicked,- sovereign grace can only keep me from constant Sin. In Christ is my hope.

Sept. 15. Another Sabbath gone - another week forever fled! I thank my Heavenly Father if I have made any progress in grace, and I do hope I have.
Listened to day to a most interesting sermon from Mr. Marshall on the Resurrection of the body. How cheering is the thought that this corruptible shall part in incorruption, and that this mortal immortality. How does it take

away the Sting of Death. This is a theme all too wondrous for our feeble minds. How does one long to be free from the mortality that the mystery may vanish away, but this is a simple longing. In God's own time he will make it clear to us. God seems more great and wise & holy than ever before. May I see and know more & more of his character and be more than ever active in his service. I find I must be constantly striving and watching & praying lest I  wander very far away from right. Lord keep me in the straight & narrow way that leads to life.

 Three weeks to day since H. left us. O may I never forget that I live in a dying world.

Sept. 22 O this precious Sabbath evening! Now everything breaths of Heaven. It does seem to me my heart goes out in love to God this night. We all feel to night as if God's Spirit was here in our midst - last week we had two public meetings wh. were very impressive. The minister from Hopkinton & five delegates visited from house to house & conversed with the people. Many seemed

to be interested, and the seriousness continues. The meetings today have been very impressive. Three experienced the hope that they have decided to be for Christ - one of them my own brother George. How can I ever be grateful enough. God has done it: He alone can move the heart to Him be the praise.

 I have been reading Mrs. Bon Temp? to night. It makes me love the missionary work more & more.  I should delight to be a missionary, were I prepared, and may I not be one here in my own Dunbarton. There are many here who have no Savior. O that God would give me strength to work for him. If what value will it be for me to bear the Christian name and yet do nothing for Christ. How can I be thus satisfied? I can not. I am not. I will try to be a more working disciple than I have ever been. With Shame, I look back on my past life, & see how much I might have done that I have left undone. Lord, if I have never truly loved thee, help me this day to begin.

Sept. 29 O that I could always feel the value of time - how infinitely precious it is. How strange it is that it must take one the whole of life to learn how to live. Why can I not see & feel the duty that rests on me as clearly as I shall when death comes. I must try to think more of dying. this will aid me to live more soberly & to improve the present time in more active and zealous labors for Christ.

 -- This wicked heart! When 'ere I think a victory gained over some sinful habit, I make some new discovery. I feel more and more that my heart is deceitful above all things & desperately wicked - none but God can cleanse me - nothing but the blood of Christ can make me pure, and like my savior.

Oct. 13- How grateful I ought to be to my God for my Sabbath privileges. It is terrible to think that there is a possibility that they may make my condemnation greater. 

   O that I could be more like Christ more meek & lowly - less irritable - it seems sometimes as if I made a little progress - God can help me

to overcome every bad habit & make me like my Savior. I will plead with him this to do. Perhaps he'll hear my cry and make me successful.  I know I do not deserve so much favor for I am a sinner. But such Christ came to save.
Oct. 26- Have been thinking how much happier we might be in this world than we are. Why need we be otherwise than happy? Surely we cannot be if we strive to make those about us happy. I think I shall make more effort to do this than I have done, with the help of God. 

                                              "This earth is full of beauty
                                               As other worlds above
                                              And if we did our duty
                                               It might be full of love."

I must learn to be more cheerful always. I will try more than ever "Almighty friend, thenceforth to Thee. A hymn of praise my life shall be. I desire also better to improve my time. Precious moment's little golden sands - let not one be wasted. How full of solemn thought is this ever vowed and ceaseless plight!

Onward, onward  they bear me towards that goal where I must one day meet them all- each laden with some thought or word or act of value, for which I must account. Will not the long train be strong witness against me, and one by one they come before me!  What memories will they bring of this sad life of sin! O can I waste again one particle of time! Weak in myself, there is help for me in One who is mighty. My Savior aid me.
___________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Dear Henry - my brother. I would not wish thee back again on earth though often comes the tear when I think of thy early removal from us, cut down in the midst of youth and health. 19 short years and thy life is done & now Death has found for thee a "quilt pillow" Thous art slumbering peacefully and angels guard thy rest. Thy soul we trust has found in Heaven its native home. Methinks I see thee near the throne raising high thy note of praise while golden harp strings quiver as they touch. How looks this earth to thee? Methinks not

altogether naught. Did not the short life up here decide thy destiny and canst thou not praise God in nobler strains for that thou wast a sinner and art now ransomed, redeemed and glorified. Dost thou not oft bethink thee of thy friends still dwelling here; and will not thy fresh spirit gladly fly to us on errand & all divine. O very near thou ?ei??t to us, & this but a short space divides us. and we shall meet then on a holier shore. Till then praise God in thy brightest home of love. And here will toil and per??t till called above.
__________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Nov. 17, O how I long to be able to say from my heart, I love this blessed day, the best of all the seven." I believe I do love it some, but whether the best - and whether come it on account of its holy associations & employments, I dare not yet affirm.
__
Dec. 8, 1850 - This sabbath is my first in Merrimack whither I come on the 2e day of this month to pass a term of ten weeks at Mr. Russell's school in this place. It is a beautiful day and I do want to go to meeting - but Mr. Russell has services in the

Seminary Building to day because the walking is bad.

  O how my spirit sighs for more ardent love to Jesus. I wish to be entirely assorbed in my savior - to love him with my whole heart - to give to him my all. Then I know I should be happy. I feel that it is the only path to true enjoyment. And I pray that religion may not be to me all a beautiful thing - a thing of the head and not of the heart. I hope I truly desire to have my inmost soul renewed & sanctified, this alone can prepare me for a glorious heaven where I may dwell with God and Christ & dear friends gone before forever.

"A spirit whose purity I could find
a perfect guide, in whose strength
perfect support - in whose love a
perfect shelter."                                                  Works of Plutarch Lives of 
"frail as the leaf in Autumns yellow bower."
"Her eyes were large, full of grey,  & brilliant, when the soul came to the windows & looked forth." E. Southwark
sober harbor of soft south winds & sleeping flowers"
An atheist midst scenes so like a God
Wilt then declare thyself an atheist
When every feature of the wondrous Alps
Which rears its cloud capt summits high above
Thee, speaks its Makers presence, and tells them, in
A voice so full of living truth and of 
Presis??s might that thou canst not but heaven hear
It. "He who created me is from above
Eternity all boundless is his realm
He is eternal the beginning &
The end. We? will?s The sca?se? of a p?? sc?ghats? 
He w?lds the sacrifice of Almighty Jesus.
Where can thy heart have journeyed to, if thou
Canst calmly say there, is no god, when thou
Art gathering in this most sublime creation.
Bid thy heart back who canst. Thy self a man
And yield it  up in grateful praise to Him
Who found these haughty peaks! This beauteous earth
In all its part, and Thee -His noblest work.
